posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
heres a recipe I made for a friend for my lasagna.

I never used a written recipe and learned from watching someone else make it. They never used a written recipe either.

all amounts were pulled out of my ass based on a best guess for the recipe. because the amounts of many of the seasonings don't matter that much. The person I gave it to said it was the best lasagna they had ever had. they had no trouble making it and never questioned me on exact measurements.

2 lbs. sweet and/or hot Italian sausage
1 package Lasagna Noodles
1 Table spoon olive oil
2 16oz. cans diced or crushed stewed tomatoes
2 or 3 lbs. Mozzarella cheese
Italian seasoning
dried chopped parsley
2 or 3 pints ricotta cheese
2 or 3 eggs
1 white onion medium to large
6 to 8 medium size mushrooms
2 or 3 cloves fresh garlic

Mix the 2 or 3 eggs, 2 or 3 tablespoons parsley, and Ricotta cheese together.

Chop the Mushrooms.

Boil the noodles in a large saucepan with the oil, and 1 tsp. salt in the water,
cook until still tough. drain and refill pan with cold water to keep noodles from
sticking together.

Coarse chop the onion, smash and finely dice 1 or 2 cloves of garlic.
Remove the sausage casing, and break up the sausage in a frying pan.
Brown the sausage with 2/3 the onion and all the garlic, salt and pepper to taste.
Drain off the grease.

In a 2 quart sauce pan combine the Stewed tomatoes, 1 tsp. Italian seasoning, the rest of the onion, 1 crushed and finely chopped clove of garlic, the mushrooms, and the Sausage.
bring to boil and then simmer about 15 minutes.

Arrange in layers in a ungreased 9x13" pan: sauce, ricotta cheese, mozzarella, and pasta.
Top the last layer with a generous amount of mozzarella.
Bake at 350 for 20 to 25 minutes or until sauce bubbles and the cheese is slightly brown.

I understand that. >>18810561
I was fucked recently by the ubiquitous "dash" of bitters. It seemed at first synonymous with a drop, considering the spout of the bitters bottle only lets a drop out at a time, but of course that's not the case. I saw proper technique videos and such online, and the bartender's estimate (1/8 tsp) but then I'm fucked again when I discover that the dasher top for Peychaud's bitters is different than for Angostura, lets a different amount through at different rates, and also Angostura seems to be more bitter per volume in general, so since most cocktail recipes assume it if unspecified, then a little extra Peychaud's is appropriate to compensate. This is stuff that is never explained in any starter guides (and you'd think they'd link a starter guide to anyone looking up recipes for the most basic cocktails)

Fudge. Bag of semi-sweet chocolate chips like you would use to make cookies with, can of sweetened condensed milk, and a tablespoon of butter. Heat up sweetened condensed milk and butter till hot then add the chocolate chips and stir quickly until they're melted then pour into a prepared pan lined with buttered parchment paper. >>18834727
there are cheaper options, but personally first i'd grab some flour. i work with a similar budget. you can do all kinds of breads, pasta/noodles, pizza dough, steam buns, etc. get some sugar (and butter if you can afford it) and you can do all kinds of deserts now too. get some basic sauce ingredients and herbs/spices, add some meat, eggs, cheese and staples for sauces (canned san marzanos, parmesan, garlic, etc) and soups and you can basically do any italian/mediterranean or northern chinese dish on the cheap, it really opens up a lot of stuff and saves a ton.

with some medium/short grain rice and fish, you can really round out your repertoire. if i had an electric pressure cooker i'd buy more beans and stuff, but i don't really crave them that often. but when i do i love some chili with jalepeno cornbread. it'd also help with making stock/broth. i hope to start doing more thai food soon but this is basically how i eat, with the odd potato or meat pastry dish thrown in there. i also buy and dehydrate bananas on sale to eat banana chips.

>>18832476
>>18832487
If OP has dagnosed celiac, then that's that. There's a test, and it's final, and then the doctors put you on the diet. Then people started making gluten-free into a fad diet (along the same evolution of Atkins and other low-to-no-carb diets) and were claiming "Non-Celiac Gluten Sensitivity" or NCGS, which is a controversial phenomenon at best in the medical literature.

It's similar with keto, which is a legit diet that existed for decades as a treatment-of-last-resort for severe treatment-resistant epileptics (we're talking one step prior to cutting their brain in half here). Then, in the same line of genesis of low-carb diets from Atkins, it became reimagined for the general public as a fad diet, even though it has absolutely fuck all to do for the general population what its original intent was.

Arguably these medically-inspired fad diets have been a net good thing for society, as they have raised at least some bare minimal awareness for horrible diseases and the requirements some people need in daily life to live through them, and have made such requirements easier for those people to meet. And while the counterargument to that is that people cite gluten-free and keto pseudoscience to be annoying self-absorbed ignorant assholes, I'd argue that those people would be annoying self-absorbed ignorant assholes anyway. (The internet in general probably makes it worse, though).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18831602
A lot of different things. Starting with a handle which is secure, grippable, but does not tire the hand with prolonged use. Then you need a blade that is rigid without being overheavy or too thick, bearing an acute edge that is sharp and durable without being axelike and inefficient. The length should be sufficient for the task without engendering drag or being unwieldy. Finally, the tip should have a form commensurate with use, being neither dangerous nor obstructive to the task. The material of the blade should be hard enough to bear work but soft enough to resist shattering force and to allow resharpening.

These are the fundamentals, and even they may shift with the purpose of the knife.

>>18831290

The best thing you can do is to walk into a store that sells knives and try holding them in your hands.

A knife you don't feel comfortable with will in hand will not be a knife you will be confident in using, and will just end up collecting rust in a drawer.

There's a good reason why Zwelling has such gigantic market share; they push hard to have their entire range on display at 3rd party retailers, and double down by setting up physical retail locations with their entire catalogue on display, including their super premium Kramers.

Because at the end of the day, at a similar price point, any normal person in the market for high end knives would rather purchase a Zwilling or Myabi they can physically hold in their hands over a Wustof or Shun they can only see online.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18835618
>Whiz is traditional
Except whiz wasn't invented when cheesesteaks were first made. Whiz was first added by Geno's to cater to Midwestern tourists who were dismayed that Pat's didn't serve theirs with the Whiz and Velveeta they were used to. After Geno's exploded in popularity with tourists, Pat's was forced to follow suit or go under. It got so bad for Pat's that all of their satellite locations had to close, leaving only the original one at 9th and Passyunk in South Philadelphia. They had a location on South Street, another on Ridge Ave in Roxborough/Manayunk and a third somewhere in Southwest Philadelphia (forgot where). The Ridge Ave location is sorta still open, but on Henry Ave and under different ownership, now called d'Alessandro's. The Ridge Ave location is actually where cheesesteak was first made in the late 1950s, several years before Whiz was even invented never mind sold in stores. Prior to that, it was just "steak sandwich" with no cheese.

>you'll get made fun of if you don't
No.

>>18835597
Any take away pizza joint in South Philly. If you're already close to Pat's/Geno's, J&J is about a block up 9th street from there and made decent cheesesteaks last time I was there over 15 years ago. Otherwise, don't go out of your way for one. Really, just about any place that isn't Pat's, Geno's, Oregon, Tony Luke's, Jim's or Phil's will be good.

>prov or whiz
Depends what you like. Whiz is for tourists and people from Northeast Philadelphia (IE tourists) and provolone is traditional while non-white people tend to prefer American cheese.

While it's possible to cook in stainless with minimal to no sticking, most people who buy babby's first stainless will fuck up at least a few times before figuring out how to use it. Especially if you've used teflon/nonstick pans your entire life, you've probably developed some bad habits in regard to the amount of heat and oil you're accustomed to using--same goes for babby's first carbon steel and cast iron. People buy them and crank the heat too high or too low, usually using little to no oil (because they think oil is unhealthy), or adding the oil or the food at the wrong times. Everything has a proper way to use it, even those teflon pans you think are so easy; I guarantee you weren't cooking anything in them on high heat with no oil, since you would have seen (and smelled) the toxic DuPont(TM) fumes coming off the pan.

>>18830501
You’re not heating it up enough. Put it on high heat and periodically a little water on it. When the droplets ball up and dances around like mercury, you know it is hot enough to add the oil.

The Leidenfrost Effect says that when the temperature of the pan gets hotter than the boiling point of water, as the water droplets hit the surface, the “bottom” of the droplet vaporizes so quickly that the vapor insulates the rest of the droplet and makes it float on the hot surface of the pan.

>>18830501
>it's completely nonstick, even when it comes to eggs and gyoza
How much food sticks is completely dependent on how much oil you use. If you want food to stick, use less oil.
>meat curls up, no crust forms unless i literally press the food item into the pan or put weights on it
Allow your meat to come to room temperature before adding it to the pan to reduce curling. Add more oil to improve heat transfer. You should be essentially shallow frying any fillets. This advice applies to any pan regardless of material.
>it does at least leave a nice fond for pan sauces
Indeed. That's why it's my favorite pan. It's great for any protein + liquid dish whether that be meat with sauce, stews, soups, stir fries, etc. Most of my dinners start with browning the meat and deglazing afterwards.

>>18834650
I like to use 2-year cheddars. I slice it thick, and leave it cold when I lay it upon the burger still in the cast iron skillet. The heat from the meat half-melts the cheese from underneath, creating a mingling interface with its surface. Then I blast the top of the cheese with a blowtorch to brown and bubble the surface for maximum flavor and texture. The inside of the slice of cheese is warm, but not melted, the bottom is melted, the top has a delicious Maillard reaction. This does not work if the cheese is too mature. This does not work if the cheese isn't cold. Upon assemblage, I spoon one teaspoonful of the beef tallow drippings over the burger/cheese/bacon section before closing it up.

>>18834584
I discovered the best cheeseburger cheese by accident:
>Leftover cheese from a Swiss fondue
You make fondue one night and made too much (or just didn't feel like stuffing your fucking face because it's fucking delicious), so after the remainder cools a bit you scoop it out, with the crusty bottom part, into a leftovers dish, and refrigerate. The next day it's firm but soft and squishy, and it is unmeltable. Slice it into thin slices (the best bits have crust) and you have an amazing cheeseburger.

Gruyere on its own is wonderful on a burger but it is stiff and will never melt in any workable fashion, so that's why this works so well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18835210
If you get charcoal just get a Weber kettle, the one with the fancy ash catcher is nice, but the cheaper one with the bullshit plate ash catcher does the job.

Go to Costco and get kingsford pro charcoal. You can usually get it on sale for 13-15 bucks for 40lbs. Also, just get the paraffin wax cubes to start the charcoal. Put it in a pyramid, walk away for 20 minutes and prep whatever you want and come back when the coals are ashed over and knock them down. Lighter fluid is awful and makes your food taste awful. Chimney starters work great, but you need welding gloves to pick one up that's started.

If you're interested in smoking meat as well as grilling, I would get a Pit Barrel. It's brainless to operate and the results are fantastic, plus you can use it as a grill.

I have an MHP Nat Gas grill which is great for basic grilling, and it's 30 years old, but they are also > 1000USD new. It's super convenient and I never run out of gas, but there's no satisfaction in using it.

Whatever you do, avoid buying chink shit from walmart or home depot, it will crap out within 18 months.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If this is your first grill go with propane. It's less work and you can control the heat more easily. Goes from cold to cooking temp in 5-10 minutes vs 30. Less cleanup, no ashes full of hot coals to deal with. Charcoal may have a slight edge when it comes to flavor but most of the time not worth the extra effort.

posts.com:
>>18836423
>could I add lemon juice to the shortbread to give it a lemon taste?
absolutely not. would ruin it. you could add lemon zest, though, or powdered lemonade mix. Just be aware that with baking, if you add something like that and throw off the ratio, you have to remove something equivalent. The reason lemon juice wouldn't work is because you don't put liquids in shortbread. Lemon zest would likely be fine on it's own without removing anything since it's basically "inert" from a baking perspective, adding lemonade mix you would probably want to remove an equivalent amount of sugar. If you added say, lemon oil, you'd want to remove an equivalent amount of whatever fat you used (which I sincerely hope is butter).

I'm not sure why you'd want to do this, though. lemon bars should be very lemony without flavoring the shortbread. Do you, by chance, have scurvy?

All these sandwich places are shit. None of them prep vegetables, none of it is fresh, it's all Sysco product that gets delivered in bags or whatnot. Pre-sliced tomatoes. "Deli meat" is an abomination. The cured meats full of soy and other fillers. The others are emulsified loaves of mechanically separated scraps. It's all a giant scam and people pay way too much for low quality garbage. If you've ever had to deal with slicing deli meats you know how disgusting it is. The bread is anemic, weak, and cakey.

I don't need sandwiches so often and so lazy that I would demean myself by buying any of this crap. It's not more expensive to buy fresh produce, bake fresh bread, and roast real meats that aren't classified as "emulsified sausage product" by the USDA.

I like real food, not literal overpriced garbage. Also, Subway fucking stinks inside.

>>18827079
>The name Champagne on a Cognac bottle refers to its origin, namely the growth area the grapes were grown in. There are six growth areas–or “terroirs”–in total, and the two that are considered to produce the finest eau-de-vie are named Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. These two premium terroirs have soil that compares to the soil of the Champagne region in Northern France. Hence the shared name.

>A Cognac is called a “Fine Champagne Cognac” when it contains a blend of eaux-de-vie from both Grande Champagne and Petite Champagne. At least 50% of the blend have to be from the Grande Champagne. When the word Champagne is used on a Cognac, it will either be preceded by the word, Grande, Petite, or Fine. This simply denotes the terroir in which the grapes were grown.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18829472
I typically use a chefs knife; I score a line where I need the cap to separate from the bottle by gently running the blade around the circumference where the bottom of the bottle cap meets the glass, then I use the back of the knife to crack the wax. Don’t worry about damaging the cork, the cork itself is attached to a plastic cap and there’s no need to remove the wax from the cap. See picrel, that’s my 1982 Delord. I’m pretty OCD so I gun for a clean cut as pictured since I like my bottles looking nice. This takes experience though. The first time you do it you’re gonna be messy, so do it on a big empty table or kitchen top where you’ve got plenty of space so you can subsequently wipe all the chipped pieces of wax off with ease. Enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous

Oh and re: the ABV, it’s honestly fine. Most Armagnac is ABV’d @ 40% (you can get higher), and I’ve had some pretty solid whisky at 40% even though I generally lean a wee bit higher for my favourites. I just had my Delord with my partner and we both agree no cheese or mushroom in the nose, palate and finish, lol. Looking at my tasting notes though, this is what I wrote: nose: extremely grape-y, like sniffing a well packed bouquet of fruits and berries packed in a basket held together by UHU glue; palate: sweet, minty and clinical, hard to pinpoint individual flavours, there’s something synthetic about the flavour but in a way I very much enjoy, it just tastes super clean; finish: the synthetic part really comes out here, plasticky but damn it’s addictive (bits of the UHU glue nose come out here on your taste buds, and just like UHU glue, it’s god damn addictive). This definitely won’t be everyone’s cup of tea, but god damn am I always in a heightened state of zen whenever I take my shot from this bottle.

>>18829703
lol yeah. Laubade does that, there’s a cloth string a few mm wide under the wax which you can just pull to get the fucker off. The problem with Delord isn’t the lack of string though, it’s that the wax is like fucking porcelain i.e. really hard. My older bottles of Laubade had no string but even despite that the wax was super easy to peel off. I typically don’t ever leave a bottle open for more than three months so I don’t have an issue with ageing becoming a problem. I typically drink one shot a day with my significant other (we do have one or two breaks a week though), sometimes we share one shot, sometimes we have a shot each; so with my rule of four open bottles at once that pretty much guarantees each bottle will finished within three months. I devised this rule mostly because for whisky it can be very unpredictable how well a bottle ages, and in my experience it’s not uncommon for shit to go downhill fast once the bottle is about 50% empty with all that air mucking about inside. Funnily enough I find Armagnac holds much better than whisky; I once had a bottle open for over a year and I still thoroughly enjoyed it. But like my current Glenfiddich 15 VAT 03 that’s open, I can tell I’m enjoying it a wee bit less now that the bottle is down to its remainder 35%. Still solid, but not quite as phenomenal as when the cap first came off.

>>18833006
Kek. In my shithole (Singapore) alcohol is taxed at a fixed value per litre or alcohol, not percentage. The sheer irony is that this basically means our alcohol tax is a poor people’s tax more than anything because for cheaper shit you pay a higher percentage in tax (since the product is cheaper but the tax is fixed): thus the more expensive your liquor the more meaningless the tax becomes (you pay the same $ per litre regardless of whether you’re buying a 20$ piss wine or a 1000$ or fuck it 10000$ bottle of scotch). Beer is thus pretty damn costly here (we’re one of the most expensive countries to buy beer in), but once you go into the 3-figure range like I dunno a Dewar’s 32, it’s often cheaper here than in Europe.

Am newfag and cooklet. Thanks for dropping by.
Tried making fried chicken, while replacing buttermilk with milk and lemon juice (saw it could work when you don't have buttermilk and I'm NOT going to buy something I can't use often compared to the wide utilities of milk and lemons). Dredged chicken in flour, milk mixture, flour, milk, and then flour again when I got a thick and chunky breading (not schnitzel-style breading with just a single dredging of flour). Fried about 10min. altogether on medium-high heat until well done and kinda burnt. Nice, hard and chunky crust, like picrel but with bigger knobs of breading, taste was mostly fine but made notes to reduce heat.

Problems : breading came off easily and underside breading was kinda moist, not dry. How to make breading stick to the chicken? Is the underside becoming wet from condensation or whatever inevitable if you want to eat hot, fresh chicken? Also, if I want the chicken to be moist (I used a breast cut in half, width-wise) after cooking should I use a lower heat? But isn't medium or higher heat and sciencey-science stuff how you get a hard crust/browning/searing/anything-tasty-that-doesn't-look-like-boiled-chicken?

What do and thanks for the help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18833798
Your title says "Homemade KFC", and, not that I don't think you can't make excellent fried chicken at home, you won't be able to make a KFC analog because they use rather expensive and sophisticated pressure fryers. I'm pretty certain that frying method set the bar for most chicken places as well like Popeyes or w/e.

Honestly, I do like pan-fried chicken from home, but these days I've sort of relegated fried chicken and other fried foods to out-of-home status. Frying is just messy and expensive, would rather go out for it. I feel the same way about pizza because I lack an expensive pizza oven.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Sounds like you do need slightly less heat, yeah, but chicken breast is always going be dried than other cuts. Draining the cooked pieces on a rack will help stop it becoming soggy. Make sure your first flour coating is thin and you knock off any excess – dry pockets of flour will make the coating fall off. Personally I marinate in sour cream then just do one coating of flour.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sounds like maybe you made too thick of a coating, or something was off with it because of the moistness. Keeping the skin on will make the inside of the coating moister because of the fat but if you used used chicken breast they probably came without skin.

Buttermilk is thicker so more flour will hang on to it without having to dip in milk twice. Just using milk and lemon doesn't sound. My experience is that purely using buttermilk (the "fake" fermented kind) will make the crust fall of easier. Best result I've had is by mixing buttermilk with egg whites.

This category of mistake is pretty typical desu. Baking powder vs baking soda (luckily many recipes explicitly require both), curry leaves vs curry powder, there's probably hundreds of common confusions for novices. Even very experienced home cooks will always be out of a required ingredient from time to time and wonder, "Why can't I substitute X for Y?" and occasionally have a catastrophic failure. (This happened to my parents on a substitution for a recipe that they had made literally hundreds of times since they were children. Fwiw I'd rather have my parents be experimenting and failing occasionally than insisting on running to the grocery, which may require driving, every time there's a minute ingredient missing.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18836304
My favorite way is standing in the backyard with the boys, enjoying a beer in the company of friends, but I'll tell you about the best way I've ever eaten a steak too.
Here in Washington, in the Puget Sound, there's a bunch of islands where rich people have vacation and retirement homes. One of them, Lopez Island, has a farm where they raise Wagyu beef. I picked up some of their steaks and cut them into thin strips. Not meat slicer thin, but pretty skinny with a knife, a little bit thinner than pic related. No seasoning. For cooking, I heated up a big dictionary-sized Himalayan salt block in the oven. Once it was hot, I put it on the table, resting in a baking tray. You just need to put the thin strips on the hot salt for a little bit. Hardly a minute, depending on the thickness of the meat. Delicious hot and salty meat strips straight from the big pink brick. I regret drinking anything during that meal, if only to have more room for more steak strips.
Or just use salt, pepper, and a meat thermometer on a grill or cast iron of your choice. Hard to go wrong with that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Broccoli is frustrating. Tenderstem is nice but boring, even steamed the construction of the typical floret means the buds will be mush and the stems hard, even when steamed, and even when steam dried. The only work around I've found is to either cut to the bone and separately cook the stem, or tenderstem boil upright to soften the stem and finish off in the pan.

Recently I've been experimenting with broccoli purees. It's a very easy out and with enough butter it comes out well. You can plate this well with other green veg on top of the puree, or even beneath a protein.

Never figured out how to make broccoli work without hiding it in something else. Any tips would be welcomed.

>>18829257
>>18829269
These are the right answers. No one is walking around with a compendium of cocktail recipes in their head. This isn't the 1950's.

Just figure out a simple cocktail that you like and stick with it everywhere you go. Don't ask for a mojito, don't ask for something gay and stupid like a singapore sling that has six ingredients. If the bartender has to touch three bottles for a cocktail, they will hate you. Don't ask for anything with red bull. Don't ask for long island iced tea unless you're in a club setting (if you don't know the difference between a club, a pub, a bar, a cocktail lounge, etc, then don't ask for a long island iced tea).

If it's a reasonably okay bar, just ask for a rum daiquiri if you want something refreshing and light. It's delicious. Rum, lime, sugar syrup, shaken hard and served ice cold. If you want something boozier and more.. "manly", ask for a Manhattan or an old fashioned. If you want something manageable that you can sip on for a while, get a highball, which is spirit + carbonated liquid: vodka soda, gin and tonic, tequila soda, whiskey soda. You can just ask for a Jameson highball and the bartender will know what you mean.

You can always ask for a whiskey on the rocks or neat and the bartender will totally respect you for it, especially if it's a nice whiskey. You'll need to specify by brand. Doesn't ask for "whiskey on the rocks", that's what fucking alcoholics and retards ask for.

Don't ask for doubles. Don't ask a bartender to "make it strong". Just order a drink like a real, normal human being who isn't a total retard and is visiting earth for the first time ever.

My usual drink order is a Victoria (mexican beer) and a fernet (italian amaro, very bitter, very unique). A boilermaker or "shot and a beer" is a common combo that will put your bartender at ease.

I went vegetarian for about a year on two different occasions, another time maybe half a year. sometimes I was vegan, not on purpose but I don't consume much dairy as it is and sometimes I'll go long stretches without it for no particular reason.
>how did it affect you
the biggest impact was that it got me out of the mentality that a meal isn't complete without a slab of meat, or that meat itself can be the entire meal, and with that I got rid of a lot of bad eating habits. it made dropping all the goyslop much easier. physically and mentally I don't think it changed me that much but I sit in a chair 16 hours a day, maybe I would have noticed changes if I was more active
>would I try it again
sure, though I don't feel much of a need to. when I went back to eating meat the amount I ate was relatively small and that hasn't changed. it's mostly salmon and pork belly, and very rarely is it the focus of the meal (like some canned salmon on a salad, a bit of pork belly to flavor beans for burritos, etc.)
>go-to meals
salad, fried rice, rice & bean burritos or bowls, japanese style vegetable curry, bibimbap, pasta, really a lot of stuff I ate before, just without meat.
>meal planning
for a little while just to see what I was missing out of curiosity, but after that I just ate what I wanted. it's not like I wasn't already missing a ton of stuff while I was still eating meat
>supplements
no
>cheaper
for me, yes, but if you're still married to meat and have to have fake chicken nuggets and fake burgers and all that shit then you will probably spend more.
>interpersonal relationships
no. I dated meat eaters as a vegetarian and vice versa when I ate meat. the only people who 'can't' date someone with a different diet are the ones who turn their diet into their personality.

My uncle used to hang pheasants by the neck in his garage for weeks until the body would fall away from the head. The stench was incredible, yet it was still safe to eat and delicious. Not all bacteria is bad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18834685
Not a freshly slaughtered duck.

There are two different types of biological food-borne pathogens, organisms that cause illness themselves (salmonella, e-coli), and organisms that produce toxins that cause illness (clostridium botulinum, lysteria monocytogenes). While contamination from the first group would make you sick, it is neutralized by proper cooking procedures. Contamination from the second group cannot be neutralized by cooking procedures, but takes time to become hazardous as the bacteria themselves aren't dangerous and must produce toxins in order to make you sick.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It depends on what do you mean by obscure

Pasta with legumes are a Italian tradition but I don't see it served often outside Italy
Most common ones are
Pasta (ditali)e fagioli (beans)
Pasta(broken spaghetti or ditali)e lenticchie (lentils)
Pasta (broken spaghetti) e piselli (peas)

The base recipe is the same for all those.
Make a soffritto (or at least just onions), optionally add pancetta cubes, put the legume, cover with water and cook it
Add the pasta in the legume water and cook, keep adding water if it become to dry
You can enjoy soupy or thicker depending on your taste

> Castagnaccio (spongy cake)
Chestnut flour, water, raisins, pine nuts, rosemary https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=geokkcVNXBE&t=61

> Acquacotta
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9-B65U7o-js&t=98

I don't know if you already knew these

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18834325
There's a general thread for coffee you know.
But anyway make it whichever way appeals to you so long as it's not instant.
Want something dead simple? Filter brew machine.
Are you willing to put in more effort for something better but still want to be pretty lazy with it? Immersion brewing, like the french press or aeropress.
Want something that's more skill based and more of a ritual for arguably better results if you master it? Manual pourover, v60 is the most popular.
Want something more concentrated but don't want to spend a ton on espresso equipment? Moka pot.
Feel like getting a new hobby? Espresso and derivatives (cappuccino, macchiato, etc.).
Want something cool but terribly impractical? Siphon.
Want to hipstermaxx? Bripe.
I could probably go on for a while but I won't.
Most methods can be good and have their ups and downs. If you want generic advice, grind your own beans, measure water temp if you're using dark roasts (so you can use lower temps like 80C or so) and let your cup cool a bit after brewing.

Funfact: the primary sugar used in sodas in the european market is made from sugarbeets using the exact same process used to produce hfcs. The reason european sodas don’t specify this is because food labelling laws are much more lax in the EU (they only have to say ‘sugar’, not what specific kind of sugar like is required in the US).

it's cheaper, the meals are easier to prepare, generally speaking it's better for your health, and you don't have to worry so much about cooking temperatures or accidentally poisoning yourself

but you shouldn't really 'be' a vegan anyway. you can make diet choices that mostly align with minimizing to eliminating animal products but then still do a burger at the company cookout or whatever. vegan purity is kind of silly and actually actively harmful if you're not managing your diet right to make sure you get all the necessary vitamins and shit. I don't have the patience to do that so I'll pop some eggs or fish into my food maybe once every couple of weeks so I know I'm not going to die of some easily preventable deficiency.

the only thing that will truly convince you though is to cook good vegan food. but don't look up vegan recipes, you're just going to get garbage health food.

>>18833367
I actually found that the key to a good french omelette or any omelette that you intend to roll and look neat and smooth is to use less fat in the cooking stage. The fat causes the egg curds to separate more easily, and less fat means the eggs will be more cohesive, smooth, and stuck to each other more. Butter can be added in the rolling stage so you have melted butter between the layers, or simply add melted butter on top of the finished omelette on the plate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My prefered way of cooking eggs is separating the yolks from the white. Cooking the whites completely either like an egg white omelette or just egg white scramble, and some light browning on whites is pretty good.

And with the yolks you can make a hollandaise sauce with lottsa butter.

you serve by putting the cooked egg whites on top of some toasted bread followed by pouring the hollandaise on top. Or make it into a sandwich and have the hollandaise in the sandwich or on the side to dip your sandwich into.

Of course you can supplement this whole recipe with bacon bits, onions, or other veggies or meat of your choice.

It's a lot of work separating the eggs and making hollandaise sauce but the end result is worth it if you have the time and the will.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18834573
Semantics and translation issues? Salsa literally just means sauce in Spanish, but typically refers to chunkier or thicker spicy chili sauces in the u.s., with the word hot sauce typically referring to bottled and more watery chili hot sauce. That being said, though in Spanish salsa can mean any sauce, it typically refers to hot chili sauces, which can be further specified by saying salsa picante.

After you're done frying, throw some diced shallots into the pan, let them get some color, then throw in some tomato paste, then deglaze with 1 part red wine and 1.5 parts beef stock. Welcome to team pan sauce, what size membership jacket do you want, we're all out of everything XXL and larger.

My parents' coffee situation is weird and, I think, a little bit funny. When I was growing up, they would drink shitty pre-ground Yuban or whatever they'd buy in bulk at Costco. About fifteen years ago, I got a part time at Starbucks, and got them a free bag of a coffee they sell called Casi Cielo, a seasonal Guatemalan coffee they sell, and probably the best whole bean coffee Starbucks carries. They fell in love with it, and asked me to hoard my free bags of coffee and ship it to them, instead of flipping it on eBay as I usually did. I haven't worked at Starbucks in about a decade, but my dad will still go to the local stores and buy up their entire supply whenever it's available, and now it's all they drink and told me they can't really stand the shitty pre-ground supermarket stuff. If they run out of that coffee, they'll switch to tea. When I visited them yesterday, I offered to grind their coffee with my hand grinder, but my mom stopped me because she immediately knew it would make a huge difference to have fresh burr-ground coffee, and she sort of didn't want to know, because she knew the financial rabbit hole coffee snobbery can lead to. They're reluctant to try better beans or better grinders, or better brew methods because they don't want to "have to" start spending more money on their morning coffee.

Water is supposed to flow evenly through it anon. You want all the water passing through all the coffee, not clogging the filter, pooling up top, and flowing around outside the bed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18823516
yh but wouldnt that brew in like a minute tops as the water sieves through it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18823549
A faster, more even extraction is still preferable to a slower uneven one. Its not all that coarse of a grind fwiw, you're just used to looking at massive amounts of fines all over the bed. Better grinders(the anon above is either using a zp6 or kafatek flat) with more narrow particle distributions will let you get away with coarser grinds, but tastier cups because you're more evenly extracting the coffee.
>This shows exactly the “common knowledge” curve I was talking about earlier; if you grind too fine, average extraction yield goes down because your extraction becomes more uneven.
https://coffeeadastra.com/2020/04/02/why-cant-we-grind-coffee-finer-for-pour-over/
>Whenever too many coffee fines get trapped in the pores of a paper filter, the drip rate of a coffee brew can go down drastically. This is not only a problem because the brew becomes much longer: the bigger issue is that whatever water is still able to pass through will do so along smaller, and unchanging paths through the filter. This means that large regions of the coffee bed will potentially stop receiving fresh water, and will remain under extracted, while other regions will receive the bulk of the flow and contribute astringency or other unpleasant flavors caused by over extraction.
https://coffeeadastra.com/2021/03/04/the-four-rules-of-optimal-coffee-percolation/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18830349
grind a bit coarser than espresso
fill the basket
level it out with a knife or something
dont tamp it or press it down
boil water
pour boiling water in base
put full basket in base
screw top on bas
put moka on the smallest burner(if you dont have gas i dont consider you a human)
put the heat to max, the flame ring should be the same diameter as the base of the moka
wait until coffee starts to flow
as soon as you cant see the silver bottom of the top half of the moka turn the heat to min
wait until the coffee reaches halfway to the bottom of the spout(you will have to eyeball this)
at this point turn the heat off
once the coffee has reached the bottom of the spout take it off the stove and run the base under cold water for 15-25 seconds making sure not to spill coffee
pour coffee and enjoy

its that simple.
also you may be getting grit because you are using a standard filter which sucks, try buying a E&B Lab competition filter. it is easily the best moka filter you can buy and it costs less than $20(im pretty sure.)

you can also put an aeropress filter on the moka filter(wet it a bit to make sure it sticks), this will make sure no fines or grit end up in the cup (and will slightly increase back pressure) but it will remove alot of the natural oils of the coffee and affect the taste and mouthfeel.
i hope this helps.
this is my method that i took from hoffmann and wired gourmet and have been using it 2-3 times every day for a year and it works perfectly every time.
if you follow this and still have problems then thats on you.

you are 100% wrong.
when making broth with bones you will get a layer of scum that forms on top of the broth after cooking for a while. to make a good broth you need to skim off this scum and throw it out.
that last 5-10% of potential liquid that sputters is the scum of the moka.
it tastes bad and will objectively taint the taste of the rest of the moka.
is it really worth it to go from 160g of tasty well made coffee to 190g bitter over extracted badly made coffee?

Nigga, wut? Cape gooseberries are delicious. Tastes like an orange, texture of a tomato and perfect snacking size. What's not to like? Did you get sour ones recently or something? Cuz they're out of season right now unless you live in Ausland or some other part of the world that doesn't matter or you had some shitty imports (srsly, imported ones are horrible for some reason).
Even so, sour ones make great jam. Bake two circular pound cakes (or do what I do and bake one square one and cut it in half diagonally), put a good layer of cape gooseberry jam between them, frost that shit with same chantilly cream (or whatever your preferred frosting is) and decorate it with cape gooseberry flowers (cut them as though you were making tomato flowers) and that shit is the taste of summer to me.

posts.com:
>>18832319
Bardzimi is just the brand, although I've never heard of that particular brand before. The drink itself is called тapхyн (tarkhun), which is literally just the Russian word for tarragon. It was created in Georgia about 100 years ago but now it's popular throughout the former Soviet countries. If you're curious it's relatively easy to make at home using sugar, soda water and fresh tarragon leaves which should be in your local supermarket.

It has absolutely nothing to do with alcohol, it's just an ordinary soda, although I have seen people using it as a chaser for vodka.

posts.com:
We'll be making kkakdugi today. Picrel, our ingredients:
>daikon radish (well, at least a type of radish that is closest to it and available here)
>Korean chili flakes (gochugaru)
>onio
>scallion
>fish sauce
>salt
>honey

Few things. Yes, I made this before, 4 times, in fact. I know that there's an online debate going on whether honey is an appropriate substitute for sugar. (Honey has anti-bacterial properties, making people think it will stop kimchi from fermenting. It does not. I'm speaking from experience.) Moving on, and regarding gochugaru, I came to the conclusion that it is an ingredient that is absolutely superior to all the alternatives, and I admit this in shame, since I'm from a culture that prouds itself for its paprika/chili obsession (Hungary).

About my choice of different types of onions: scallion &... "regular" onions. I just like the difference in texture, basically. And lastly, about the quality of my salt... I admit, it's substandard. Koreans emphasize that it should be the coarsest salt you can get - mine is not. Apoligies.

If you join this thread: progrock posting is welcome as thread bumps.

OP here, good for you.

If I can share a little secret with you: I was initially rather skeptical of your culture's whole cuisine. I've read Reddit posts where expats complained about how "moving to Korea" was a chore and rather a let down, because everybody was consuming kimchi there and it made people farting. I'm not even joking, dude, you can just check me on google. People are complaining about (Worst) Korea being a bad place to be, because they fart so much, lmao.

I think this has to do with the "general" kimchi being produced and consumed, namely cabbage-based (the most standard) kimchi. Cabbage, in general, has glucosinolates and goitrogens, both of which are anti-nutrients that irritate the human bowels.

In any case, I made Korean bone broth (Sagol-gukmul 사골국물) for this Xmas for my sister, and the recipe called for "having daikon kimchi" on the side, so naturally I looked into it.

Turns out, "daikon" (or, similar alternatives in my country) are dirt cheap and abundantly available. Made me appreciate it, especially in these high-inflation situation right now.

Fuck capitalism, BTW.

(I've actually met some socdem [Worst] Koreans in an international political setting who were complaining about your gov. basically repressing any pro-worker movement since the end of the war. My general impression? They were very nice, but desperate people.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I know that in moderation is a tired cliche but it still is generally true for an omnivore. We've got humans from across the dietary spectrum in history and I do not know of any severe difference in health/survival rate as long as you were getting the essential nutrition. I do know that in looking at mummies from Egypt, Meso/South America and the Arctic regions they found just about the same levels of heart disease despite the highly varied diet (and near exclusive meat consumption to the latter). Leading to a conclusion that heart disease is kind of just an inevitability of age.

https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2013/03/09/173918712/hardening-of-human-arteries-turns-out-to-be-a-very-old-story
>Well, the same research team did another study, broadening the the analysis to include mummies from three other preindustrial populations: 51 ancient Peruvians, five Ancestral Puebloans of the U.S. Southwest and five Unangan of Alaska's Aleutian Islands. They also included 76 more ancient Egyptians.
>Ultimately, calcium deposits signifying atherosclerosis were not hard to find across the four different cultures. More than a third of the 137 mummies showed signs of probable or definite hardened arteries, with 25 cases of calcification in the walls of preserved arteries and another 24 along the expected course of an artery.

I prefer beef but I will concede that pesco-vegetarianism with chicken/chicken products is likely the healthiest option. But the only reason to go vegan is pure emotionalism. And in terms of red meat the more smoked/processed shit is not as healthy for you but it's also not going to kill you if it's in moderation. You look at the nutrition of bacon and you'd have to eat a stupid amount to actually really be unhealthy.

Unironically, yes. Sea bugs come from the sea (duh) but that means they essentially live their whole lives in brine, so they basically come pre-seasoned and are therefore naturally more palatable. The meat that remains is firm and rewarding to eat once cooked. Small sea bugs where you'd have to crunch through unpleasant black detritus for very little noticeable sustenance isn't typically offered for consumption. Why should bug bugs even be considered?

But the next day, a different seat

The stomach aches, the gut in pain
The fiery noodles, still remain
A battle wages, deep inside
As the stomach tries to subside

The toilet calls, a siren's wail
A journey, no one should be hailed
But the spicy noodles, oh so bold
Leave a trail, that must be told

So heed the warning, with each bite
For the next day, may not be bright
But still the noodles, we'll devour
For the spicy taste, holds such power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18832725
This is the whole reason stock was made the way it used to be. So you could make a separate sauce.
You need to do a two stage process building up flavour. You start with making your stock how you likely normally do with browned bones. Then you brown some meat and mirepoix. Degrease it. Then pour some of the first stage liquid in just to almost cover the meat.and reduce it to a glaze. Repeat this multiple times then add all the stock and simmer until the meat has no more flavour left. Strain, and that is your stock.
